mn138:3.1:
Also at [iti94:2.1](). | For _vikkhittaṁ visataṁ_, see [an5.51:3.4](), where a river is “dispersed and displaced”; [an4.246:3.4](), where a lion ensures that his limbs are not “disordered or displaced”;  [sn51.20:6.2](). At [sn51.20]() the four bases of psychic power are “scattered and diffused” due to sensual pleasures. | _Asaṇṭhita_ in the sense “not stuck” is also found in the phrase “not stuck in the formless” at [snp3.12:49.2]() = [iti51:3.2]() = [iti73:4.2](). See also [sn22.70:1.4](), and the phrase “when I stood still, I went under” 
 at [sn1.1:1.7]().
mn138:10.2: “Features” (_nimitta_) are the aspects of sense experience that provoke a response. Compare the standard passage on sense restraint (eg. [mn27:15.1]()), and [mn137:8.3](), where one is “preoccupied” with a sight giving rise to pleasure, etc.
mn138:12.3: _Samādhi_ is the outcome of letting go ([sn48.9:4.2]()). This passage reminds us that letting go also applies to _samādhi_ itself, so one should not be content to rest on one’s laurels.
mn138:14.2: Text has “equanimity” in the first case, “bliss with equanimity” subsequently.
mn138:16.3: The solution to being “stuck internally” is to continually deepen _samādhi_ by deepening letting go, not, as taught by some 20th century meditation teachers, to avoid it out of fear of becoming attached.
